performance.p: First performed at the New Strand Theatre, under the management of Miss Swanborough, on Monday, July 4, 1859.

list.item: Colonel Lord Arthur.—Scarlet military frock, laced with gold— white silk stockings, reaching above knee—gilt garters and paste buckles—high quartered shoes, with paste buckles and red heels— sword—ruffles—white laced cravat—flaxen wig.
Sir Basil.—Chocolate suit of the time, trimmed with gold lace—black wig.
Lady Amaranthe.—Rich satin open dress of the time.
Perkup.—Dark open dress—white stomacher and petticoat—flat cap, with ribbons.

div.stage: SCENE.—A Handsomely Furnished Boudoir in the house of Lady Amaranthe Allwill—Old-fashioned furniture, doors, C F. R. and L.—a toilet table, R.—on another table, L. a box of crayons and a portfolio.

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: (occupied arranging the toilet table)What a temper my lady is in to-day! No possibility of cheering her! To be sure, what is a poor widow to do? Without her opportunities for coquetry, she is no better than a judge without a wig—a soldier without his red coat—or a fool without his cap and bauble—a senseless and insipid thing! Ah, here she is!Enter Lady Amaranthe Allwill, R.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (going to sit at the toilet table)Ah! there you are, Perkup!

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: Yes, your la'ship!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Have any of my despairing lovers called to-day?

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: Let me see. Inprims, Lord Arthur Bramble.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: To see whether I was not engaged in a flirtation before cock crow, I suppose. There's nothing so insupportable as a jealous lover. He gives himself all the tyrannical airs of a husband, and deserves to be treated accordingly.

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: In seconds, Sir Basil Bodkin.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: As a disappointed courtier he can afford to wait. No other?

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: Is your la'ship expecting any one?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: No one. I don't mean to be visible to-day; my vapours are getting as thick as a November fog—to not a soul. (with hesitation) Only, if that, that—what's his name?—that Mr. Frankland should call—the young painter—you know— about my portrait, let him come in. I might give him a sitting. Heigho!

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: Yes, your la'ship! (aside) Hum! has the young painter touched up my lady's fickle heart? (aloud) I think I hear voices in the ante-room—shall I see, your la'ship? (going to C. D., and looking out) Lawks! if it isn't Mr. Frankland himself!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (with suppressed satisfaction)Ah!

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: Shall I tell Taggs to let him in?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: That head of yours has about the value of one of your toilet pins, Perkup! Didn't I say so, already? Admit him! Stay! I'll give an eye to my attire in my room—I don't want to look quite a fright—on account of this tiresome sitting! (aside, going R.) Ah! he has come, then! Exit R.

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: (going, C. D.)Walk in, sir! Enter Sir Aubrey Glenmorris, simply dressed. Her la'ship will attend on you immediately! (aside, after examining him—pertly, going) Well! I must say for her la'ship's taste, he does look more like a pictur' than a pictur'-dauber! Exit R.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (suddenly changing his simple manner to that of a man of fashion, and flinging himself into a chair)'Fore gad! I hope she won't leave me long alone, or I shall be forced to a tête-à-tête with my own conscience. And that same vixen conscience might be after telling me a host of wicked truths, such as “Sir Aubrey Glenmorris, you are a confounded rake, for you are blessed with a wife of your own—or cursed!”—conscience is not quite clear on that point, “and you leave her to vegetate amidst turnip tops and cabbages, while you—the fine gentleman in town—make love to a provoking. piquante, seductive widow! Sir Aubrey, you are a cheat and a swindler! for, lest your beauty should discover that you are a married man, and your court but little honorable, you sneak into her house under a false name and disguised mien! Sir Aubrey, you are a scoundrel, for—” Prithee, Madam Conscience, hold your peace! You are as cantankerous a tattler as a disappointed old maid! and I will have none of your company! Ah! I think I hear the widow coming!

div.stage: Enter Lady Amaranthe, R., with Perkup—Lady Amaranthe and Sir Aubrey curtsey and bow, with formality.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I must not be disturbed in my sitting, Perkup! This picture must be a secret—a secret! D'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: La! your la'ship need not say it twice. We poor girls are bred to our trade of secrecy, though it is harder work than you may think; for there's mighty little distance from the ear to the mouth! Exit C.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: At last, my dear Lady Amaranthe, I see you again. Had you known my impatience—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I should have valued it at a low brokerage, probably!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: You're vexed—you expected me, then?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Vexed! Expected you, indeed! Your vanity, at least, I see I must put at a high figure!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: I was prevented leaving home by a tiresome intruder, whom I longed to fling out of my window! (aside) Only as it was my wife's uncle, I couldn't in decency.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Fie, Mr. Frankland! I thought you a man of spirit; but if you have no better entertainment than your domestic affairs, I might as well submit to a tête-à-tête with old Mrs. Fondlechit!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Nay, then, if I am pressing, 'tis you provoke me to it!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I provoke you to be pressing? Oh, the impertinent—

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Yes! you give me my diploma to profess what conversation I please! Mine shall be of my ardour—my adoration —my burning heart—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Stop, stop! or I shall call “fire!” Your heart. indeed! I'll wager now, 'tis like some of your Spanish wines with never a flavour at all, till it gets a fine fiery taste by its transport over the tongue!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Cruel woman! You know my heart is weak! 'Tis in your hands, and 'twere a want of generosity to crush it!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Out on you! Why, your male hearts always get stronger and sounder by plenty of hard work, than they would by gentle nourishment! Well! you may talk of your heart, if you promise not to talk nonsense—but that's impossible! And so, on second thoughts, I forbid the conversation. Well, don't pout! and you shall talk of it—but not until you have finished my portrait! Now, this is at least the tenth sitting I have given you, or verily, I believe the baker's dozen—and not a stroke have you made, idler!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)And for very good reasons, I don't know how to hold a pencil!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Take your portfolio, and make something passably handsome of me.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Make! What have I to make, when your own charms—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Hush, hush! Not a word until my portrait is completed —I'm called a horrid tyrant! Well then, there's my ultimatum!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Tyranny indeed! 'Tis monstrous—barbarous!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I hate pouting, it spoils the face! Come, I'm waiting!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Your pardon, madam! I decline painting your portrait!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Is the man mad? Why does he refuse?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (sulkily)Why, because—because I don't choose—not but that I am as capable as another of—certainly I am—but— but—(tenderly)—where is the painter who could flatter himself ever to reproduce that beauty? Those eyes at once so full of softness and provoking malice—that intoxicating smile—that lovely mouth, every pearl of wit falling from which must be seized to give its true expression—those hands—that form—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Stop, for mercy's sake! I am out of blushes, if you are not out of breath!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: 'Tis a task beyond human power, and the first moment I saw you my poor talent was gone for ever—my art forgotten —my sole thought the desire to be admitted into your house— my whole life devoted to dying at your feet!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! A pretty life's occupation! But you are not dead yet.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: But I shall be soon, to see you bestow your smiles on the hundred male flirts who flutter around you.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: A hundred! Flatterer! But a poor twenty at most! And such as they are too! Even the half of the wretched score count for nothing! Besides, they tell me I have not got a heart!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: A too capacious one, perhaps—but give in it a place for one who—(about to kneel)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Hush! (aloud) You must find another attitude for me, Mr. Frankland—there's something too constrained in that!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)The coquette—but she was touched!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Well, Perkup, did I not order you—

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: Your la'ship certainly did—but your la'ship has given me full powers, if your la'ship pleases to remember, to transgress orders, according to the imperiosity of circumstances.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Heaven help us! the girl talks like a Minister of State, called to account by the Commons! What is it?

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: It is a lady urgently desires to see your la'ship alone, and will not be refused. I tried on the vapours, your la'ship; but that's no excuse for one of our own sex, as your la'ship knows.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Did she give her name?

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: She said your la'ship was probably ignorant of her present appellation!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: How does she look?

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: She wears a travelling mask, your la'ship—but her tongue wags more like a lady's than a—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Than a waiting woman's—good! My curiosity is piqued—Mr. Frankland, you must excuse me! Where curiosity is in the case, the male sex must give place, you know. Mr. Frankland, our sitting is dissolved. (curtsies) Perkup, admit this strange visitor! Exit Perkup, C. D.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: But tell me when I may return?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Well! my afternoon's reception is open to all the world!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: And I am to be treated like all the world?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Presumption! of course. What would the man have next? A good day, sir! (Sir Aubrey bows, piqued, and goes C. D.) No, no! by yonder suite of rooms! (points L.) And the other stair—there, go! (Sir Aubrey lingers—she holds out her hand—he kisses it) How you mumble! (pulls away her hand) I vow I am a great deal too good to you—not a word!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside, going)Hum! I have made progress—look to yourself, fair widow! Exit L.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (looking after him)I must confess that the wretch is charming—fascinating in manner—in look—in language! Is it possible I can have any regard for a young man without name or fortune, surrounded by a certain mystery? And then, poor Lord Arthur—ah! I begin to believe that I have a heart; for I tremble to ask it a serious question. Pshaw! away the thought now!

div.stage: Perkup introduces Lady Glenmorris, C.—she is masked, and seems nervous and embarrassed.

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: (aside)So the young painter is dispatched down the back stair, for all the world like a favoured lover, as I'm a waiting woman! (Lady Amaranthe curtsies—Lady Glenmorris looks at Perkup.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Perkup, leave us!

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: (aside, going)Really, if I am always sent away at the interesting moments, I must have it considered in my wages! Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And now, madam, if you will do me the honour to inform me—

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (taking off her mask)Amaranthe!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mabel! Mabel Templeton! the companion of my childhood—my old friend whom, for many years I have lost sight of! Welcome! welcome!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Yes—I am she—in all but name!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You are married?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: To Sir Aubrey Glenmorris!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Sir Aubrey Glenmorris? Stay! surely I know the name—but I certainly have never seen him—and is he young— handsome?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Yes—young and handsome!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And are you very happy, sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (hiding her face in her handkerchief)Oh! Amaranthe!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Ah! I see! another poor connubial victim! Oh, those vile monsters of men! Come, calm yourself, my dear! Sit down here, and tell me all about it—you don't know the good it will do you! (leads Lady Glenmorris to a sofa) I'll wager all my courtly adorers to one bumpkin, now, it was a love match!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Yes! and at first my husband lived only for me, and I was so, so happy, alone with him in the country—always alone! I devoted myself to him—refused to see a single importunate visitor!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Oh, I see! Dear, dear, dear! This is to be a confession of mistakes!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: How a mistake, when I did all to please him? But, in a little time—I don't know how—he grew weary— sulky—pouted—and when I asked him why, actually quarrelled with me! I cried—he scolded—at last I lost patience—overwhelmed him with reproaches—and what do you think he did?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Left you, and came off to town!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Yes! where, for three long months he has only written to me once, and then to propose an eternal separation. But I answered that I loved him still—should always, always, always love him, and never would consent—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I thought so—another awful error!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Do you think so? But how did you know this?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I guessed it only! My dear, they are all alike! On the matrimonial field as soon as the woman shows fight, the man deserts his colours! And so you've followed him to town?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Oh, but in secret! I would not have him know the step I have taken for the world!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: That's right, my love, try a little deceit with him —you have been too open hearted.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: That's what uncle Templeton said. He wrote to tell me that my wicked husband was making love to some horrid vile coquette, whose name he had not learned. “Had you been a coquette yourself,” he added, “you might have entered the field against this woman; but you know nothing of the art—the more's the pity—for it ought to form a notable part of a girl's education.”

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: As I live, your uncle Templeton is a man of uncommon good sense.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: His words gave me a new idea, a very extravagant one, I fear. I thought if any one could but teach me the art of coquetry—show me how to lure him back from my terrible rival—regain his tenderness! A woman is never too old to learn.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Not that art, my love!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I have heard that my former friend, Lady Amaranthe, was a widow, and that she was cited in the world as— as—oh, pardon me—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (laughing)As a professed coquette! And you journed to town to take lessons of me? Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I feared to anger you!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Anger me, sweetheart? I never was more flattered! So, so the world grants me a diploma; and my reputation brings me pupils! Ha, ha, ha! Charming! delightful! I feel already as if I had a doctor's cap upon my brow!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Then you will not refuse?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (with mock airs of gravity)Refuse you! I am proud that the first postulate in my School for Coquettes should be the noble Lady Glenmorris! (changing tone, and kissing her) My own dear charming Mabel Templeton!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Ah! you are kind as ever! You are happy, I see!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Happy! Do I know what is happiness?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: To be loved!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Indeed, my sweet simplicity! Then I ought to be supremely happy—at least if I were to believe all those odious men swear to me, which, thank my stars, I don't!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: You have so many adorers! Ah! I don't wonder at it!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Flatterer! But be easy, sweetheart—Sir Aubrey Glenmorris is not upon my list.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: And is there none you love?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Love! They will tell you a coquette is incapable of love! But the heart is a problem—that's an old story ever new—and who knows? there may be a preferred one!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Ah! I see there is!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (smiling)Perhaps! but more of this hereafter. You are my guest, love—you remain with me.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I presumed upon your goodness. The coach still waits below.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
I will give orders that your trunks be removed. (rings)
Enter Perkup, R. Perkup, see that yonder rooms, (points, L.) be prepared for my friend—

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (low to her, interrupting)Forbear to mention my name—should it get abroad—reach my husbands ears—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Good! (to Perkup) For my friend Mrs. Templemore. (low to Lady Glenmorris) That name will do?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (low to her)Excellently well.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Let her trunks be carried thither and unpacked. (to Lady G.) Then, sweetheart, the attack shall commence in full uniform of flounces and furbelows.

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: (going)A mighty deal of whispering. If her la'ship goes on in this way with me, I shall have to give her warning. Exit, C. D.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (going to Lady G., who has reseated herself)And while my fellows and Perkup see to these affairs of state, why should not we have our first lesson? (sits by her, with comic airs of importance) I have seen at a glance, young woman, the cause of all your sorrows. You loved your husband too well.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Ah! but how to lure him back?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Love him less.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: You must find some other way. That's too difficult.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (changing her manner)Why, make believe, then, sweetheart. Are you a woman and cannot dissemble? Look ye, my love, men only value what they have not, or what they are like to lose—let them doubt of their possession, and they will first try to hold it. The fish will swim round and round the still bait, look at it, and turn tail with contempt; but withdraw it gently, and he'll snap at it, and swallow it, hook and all.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (puzzled)Oh! ah!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You did wrong to shut yourself up alone. You should have seen company—attracted gallants around you. There's no lack of game, love. Never mind on whose coveys you poach. 'Tis a first general rule; you embrace your dearest friend, and you carry off her lover—every day practice dear.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: But if your admirers should become too ardent?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Oh! there are a thousand means to keep them in their place—a disdainful silence, or a burst of laughter, a sudden attack of the vapours, or the spasms—tears or swoonings, as a last resort.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Oh, dear! oh, dear! But that's shockingly complicated. How ever can I get all this into my poor head?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You are right, love. Theory is a sorry school without practice. Stay, you shall see me at work—I will give my orders. (rings) Example is better than precept. Ha, ha, ha! I verily grow an old professor in sententiousness. Enter Perkup, C. D. The vapours are gone, child. Tell my fellows that I'll see the world to-day.

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: Your la'ship is most appoppos in all your la'ship does. For there's Lord Arthur Bramble without, a tearing and a swearing—saving your la'ships presence—and a threatening to rounce all your lacqueys. I verily thought, your la'ship, he'd have spitted 'em all on his sword, like a row of larks for roasting. Poor Taggs was nigh swooning outright—I'll give you my life he was, your la'ship.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Well! we'll save poor Taggs's life by seeing Lord Arthur. Exit Perkup, C. D. You are in luck, sweetheart; with a jealous, fiery, earnest lover, there's the best opportunity for a lesson in coquetry.

div.stage: Perkup shows in Lord Arthur Bramble, C. D.—he looks ferociously at her—she utters an exclamation of affected terror, and runs out, C. D.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (angrily)Your ladyship's most devoted slave! Oh! slave is the word—negro-slave! (down, R.)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (laughing)Gracious, my lord Arthur! Are you rehearsing for the jealous man in the play, and seeing how a ferocious frown becomes you? Oh, lud what's the matter with the man? He does it as natural as life.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: What's the matter with me! lost patience is the matter. Twice I have presented myself, a humble suppliant, at the door of lady Aramanthe Allwill, and twice—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I beg you, greet my friend, Mrs. Templemore.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (bowing)I have the honour. And twice I have been—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: She is charming, is she not?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (without looking at her)I'm enchanted! Outraged —driven from your door like a—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: With that sweet air of timidity she looks like an angel.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Yes, like an angel—like the vilest beggar!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Lud! what does the man mean? My friend looks like a beggar?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Yes, like a—no, no, no! I was speaking of myself?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Is it possible? I protest I did not hear.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Since the expostulation of my calm and respectful passion, madam—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Calm! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (continuing)Cannot touch your marble heart, I retire from my suit—I tear the ungrateful woman from my heart—I leave you, madam—I leave London—I leave the world, for ever, madam—do you understand? for ever!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Not at all. I never could comprehend the words “for ever.”

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: I shall have the honour of teaching your ladyship what they mean. (goes up, but stops at the door)

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (low to Lady A.)Poor man! I feel for him.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (low to her)Oh, sweetheart, if you come to pity these creatures, you are a lost woman.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I must never pity?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Never! Do you think the man is going? Pshaw! As a general rule, you must always believe the contrary of what you hear. (aloud) What not gone yet, Lord Arthur?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: No, madam—but I am going—I am going—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (curtseying)At your will. I don't detain your lordship.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (comes down a little)You drive me from your presence, then?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes, better so, for my own peace of mind. (sighs coquettishly)

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (coming down fully)For your own peace?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes, yes, enough! I thought I had a friend—go! you had better go. I will command my feelings, strive to forget the past, wrench from my heart an affection that might have taken root—

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Well, well! I will admit I was too rash—but when I feel—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: So, you confess! shall I overlook your folly then?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Yes—but promise me in turn, that you—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: That I will forgive you—shall I? Well! this time I think I may. (gives her hand)

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (kissing her hand)Did you but know—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (pulling her hand away)I know—that's quite enough.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (aside)I am a fool to be thus wheedled. But faith, she exercises a witch's spell upon me.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (C., turning to Lady G.)Well! what do you say?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (low to Lady A.)It's astonishing—how easy it seems to be!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Practice, my love! with practice I doubt not to find you as ready a proficient.

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: Sir Basil Bodkin to kiss your la'ship's hands.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Admit him. Exit Perkup, C. D.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (aside, vexed)One fool will follow another now, like sheep at a hedge gap. (goes up, R.)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (apart to Lady G.)'Tis my lay-figure, sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Your lay-figure?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes, the figure I dress up with my seeming attention, when jealousies are to be excited—deserters recalled. The creature, in his solid conceit is so confidant of ultimate success, that he always thinks he advances, even when he is thrown back, like lumber in a corner. It's the most useful piece of furniture in a coquette's boudoir. I'll lend it to you to begin with, till you select one of your own.

div.stage: Enter Sir Basil Bodkin, C. D.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: Loveliest of your sex—(seeing Bramble) So, he's before me—but I don't fear him, egad! (to Lady A.) Loveliest of your sex!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Oh! if you repeat yourself, Sir Basil, I cannot listen to you.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: Can I reiterate too often the profession of my opinions?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Certainly not. They have wavered so frequently as courtier, that the assurance ought to be repeated for belief.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: I cry you mercy! As a diplomatist, I have never erred.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Indeed! Have you seen my jeweller as I desired?

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: I admit I was oblivious.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And you dare appear before me as unerring?

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: My mind was too full of the thought of you, fair lady, to think—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (affecting anger)To think of me at all, I suppose. You had better retire, and refresh your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: I will refresh them at the fountain head.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Nay, I don't mean to bestow on you a single sup of my regard for the whole day, as a punishment.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (aside)That woman adores me—I'm sure of success.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (low to Lady Glenmorris, L.)How he takes my buffets, eh? See how I shall now play them off. (aloud) Since Sir Basil has proved so false, I suppose I must choose you, Lord Arthur, as I have no choice left, to be my cavalier to-day.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (approaching, R.)Ah, Lady Amaranthe—at last, then—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Unless, indeed, Sir Basil is very penitent. (Bramble turns away)

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: As a monk after a full meal on a Friday.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: That's not very reassuring. So I think it must be Lord Arthur. (Bramble approaches again) He would not have treated me thus I am convinced, and the poor man merits—

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Yes, my devotion merits a recompense!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Oh, if the creature is so confident, I must not encourage him. Sir Basil, I think it must be you, after all—for want of a better—or shall I take Lord Arthur? (they Both approach eagerly) Ha, ha, ha! you'll fight, I fear, if I take one or the other. So on second thoughts I will take neither.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (turning away)Heartless coquette!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (turning up)'Tis only to teaze that poor devil!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (to Lady G.)Well, sweetheart, are you satisfied with your lesson?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I should be an ungrateful scholar were I not?

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: Mr. Leonard Frankland, to wait on your la'ship again.

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: (going)I have made a slip, it seems. I see I've got something still to learn in her la'ship's school. Exit, C. D.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (aside)That's the painter. There's nothing to fear there. (goes up)

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (aside)The canvass-dauber! He's in nobody's way. (goes up)

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (low to Lady A.)You colour, surely.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I! you mistake! Well, to you I will admit—the preferred one, perhaps—I scarce know myself—is he.

div.stage: Enter Sir Aubrey Glenmorris, C. D.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside)I am curious. Ah, my husband!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: My friend, Mrs. Templemore. (goes up with a glance at him)

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)My wife here! under another name!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside)He her lover—the preferred one! oh!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside)What have I done? Ah! (grows faint)

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)Has she discovered?—come to upbraid—shame me? She does not speak! Then curse me if I do!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
(coming down to Lady G.)What do you think of
him, sweetheart—is he not—But what's the matter? you look ill—faint!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: It is nothing—my journey—the fatigue.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Will you retire to your own apartment?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Yes, yes. (aside) Confusion ties my tongue! But leave him to her! Oh, no! (gets to door, L., and stops)Enter Perkup, C. D.

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: There's Mr. Fripperycourt, your la'ship, and Captain Simper, and Lord Faddle, and Counsellor Braybabble, and a host of other gentlemen, that I vow and pertest I can't find breath to expound to your la'ship.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Good lord! my boudoir will be taken by storm! I must march myself and meet the invasion. Exit Perkup, C. D. Sir Basil, my essence-box. Lord Arthur, my fan. (they give the articles) Mr. Frankland—(aside) No, it won't do to encourage the man too much at once. (aloud) Lord Arthur—no! I won't have you—you are always so spasmodic—Sir Basil, your hand. (aside) He's the least compromising.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (giving his hand with an air of conceited triumph— aside)I knew she must come to me.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mr. Frankland will swell my train?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (aside)'Sblood! I shall have to cut off somebody's ears—that's very clear! (Lady Amaranthe goes out with Bodkin, C. D.—looking back at Glenmorris—Bramble follows in a rage—then Glenmorris looking back at Lady Glenmorris—the doors are closed)

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Oh, I cannot bear this! I must follow, and— (seeing Glenmorris) Ah!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (opening the door, C. violently, and then closing it behind him)What does this mean, madam? How comes it you have left the country without my will?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: It seems you left it without mine.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: As if that were a reason! What means this false name?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I have only followed your example.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: As if that were to the point! I am here for certain reasons—political reasons—matters that women cannot understand. But you come as a spy upon my acts—to ruin me.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Oh, no, no.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Why, then, are you here?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Aubrey, you frighten me. Listen with a little patience—I don't reproach you—the love I bear you is strong enough to pardon all, for I love you—I have never loved but you—while you—

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: What are reproaches, if not such words as these?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside)There, he turns away again! Ah, if I could but practise my lesson. (aloud) Well, I am not devoid of power to please—I will prove it to you, Aubrey. I'll receive company—the men shall pay me court. That will flatter you.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: A notable project, truly!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: But in reality I shall love only you.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Ah, the old story again!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (vexed)Well, no—I shan't love you—I won't love you—I don't love you—there!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (piqued)Oh, indeed! How's this?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (as before)Do you think it will be so difficult a task to cease to love you?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (as before)Perhaps not. You have done all in your power to prove your good will to that intent.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: By thwarting me in all my wishes—driving me from my quiet house, when all I desired was a peaceful retreat.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: As a proof of which you never were at home.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Because you made that home insupportable.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Because you had the vilest of tempers, and rendered me wretched with your tyranny.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: There was an excellent means of escaping it, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: By the separation I demanded.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside)Good heavens!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: And now, since we are so wonderfully of one mind, I renew my offer.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside)What have I done? And no friend to aid me. Ah, men only value what they have not, she said—or what they are like to lose. Let them doubt of their possession, and they will first try to hold it. 'Tis a dangerous game—but perhaps the only one.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Well, madam, have you considered?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I have, sir. Let the deed of separation be drawn. I will sign it with pleasure—with delight. It will be the happiest day of my life.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: All I have to request is, that you will lose no time in taking measures to release me from a tie that is odious to me.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: We shall both be free then—both! just as if we had never been married. Ha, ha, ha! I feel the effects already on my spirits.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Lady Glenmorris!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Why that frown, Sir Aubrey? Look like me— laugh, sing, be gay. Ha, ha, ha! my toilet table awaits me. You must excuse me—sorry to be so rude. (curtseys—aside, going) If I stayed another moment, it would be all over with me—I should burst with grief. Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Whew! I am confounded! Can this be Mabel? Certainly—'twas not that I expected. Well, so be it—I have no longer a reproach to make myself. Yet, zounds! she might have cast me off with more decency—with some little appearance of regret. Pshaw! my whole heart—my whole soul shall be Amaranthe's now. Yes, for her my every thought. Could I have supposed that Mabel had so little real affection for me? Confound it! I deserved better at her hands! Ah, my widow!—but not alone! (retires)

div.stage: Enter Lady Amaranthe, C. D., followed by Bramble.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (aside)What can have detained him! (seeing Glenmorris) Ah, he is still here, poor fellow! (aloud) Enough, my Lord Arthur—you are as oppressive as a Muscovite tyrant in his humours, and as importunate as a linkboy on a gala-day.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (R.)I think I have reason for the most importunate humours, when you smiled on every fop in the herd, and have now dismissed them in haste—what for? To receive some more favoured swain in tête-a-tête, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Oh, the monster! Maybe, you will argue that I have sought a rendezvous with that gentleman in my boudoir! (points to Glenmorris.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Certainly not. You can't deceive me with such a vain pretext.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (aside) Who will say that jealousy is not blind? (goes to sit, R.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (going to Glenmorris)Is it true that you awaited my lady for a sitting?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (L.)With impatience.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Oh, ah! that's a different thing. (sits)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Lud! My Lord Arthur, you surely don't mean to turn into a fixture?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: You may go on with the portrait just as if I were not there—I won't say a word.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: As if a volcano could help exploding! I won't have it—indeed I won't. Now go, and send Mrs. Perkup to me to arrange my hair for the day. (aside) To give orders to have no one else admitted.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (getting up)Needs must when—a fair lady drives —I leave you, then—I leave you. (aside) I won't budge from before her door. (going, C.)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (aside)At last! Enter Sir Basil Bodkin, C. D. Another! was ever poor woman so beset? No possibility of a little quiet flirtation!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)Confound the pragmatical fool! Not a word can I have with her alone!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (advancing pompously, L. C.)'Tis only I! (Lady Amararthe shrugs her shoulders) I knew the general exclusion could not be meant for me. I can never present myself at a wrong time—never.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (with humour—C.) No—you arrive like destiny, which there is no avoiding.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (aside)I knew I was right. (up C.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (aside)I must e'en resign myself, and seek another opportunity.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (aside—R.)It can't be that fool either, she expects—but if she does not repeat her order, torture me if I stir.

div.stage: Enter Lady Glenmorris, L., more handsomely dressed.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)She too now! The devil himself must surely shuffle the cards to spite me.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: There you are, sweetheart—recovered, I trust.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Entirely. (crossing to C.—to Bramble) Glad to find you still here, Lord Arthur. (smiles)

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (aside)Ye gods! what a smile was there—eh, eh!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (to Bodkin)Sir Basil, too, is always welcome. (smiles.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (aside)'Gad! that was a dead shot at me. And what a pair of eyes!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (to Lady Amaranthe)Methought my travelling dress became me ill—so I have spent a few moments at my toilet. (low to Lady Amaranthe, by whom she sits) You advised me to neglect no chance. (the Ladies talk low together.)

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (conceitedly)By all the divinities of Olympus, that woman has taste! (goes up, L.)

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: She must have a design upon some one in this room. (crosses to C.)

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Yes, yes—she cast a glance this way—and such a glance! There, look—again!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: You think so?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: I'm sure. (to Glenmorris) It can only be for you or me—and as it is not for you—why, it's very clear—

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (dropping down, C.)And me—and me. I presume I count for some one.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Now, Sir Basil, really you distress me!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (angrily)My lord, my successes are undoubted. (goes up, C.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Where could have been my eyes just now? She's positively charming.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Oh, pooh, pooh! so—so—country manners.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: No—there's a grace and a distinction. Besides, she can be formed—and egad! I'll take the task upon myself.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (uneasy)You, my lord!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: And may I never find grace with woman, if I don't obtain some favour of her within half an hour. Besides, it will be a good card to play off against Lady Amaranthe. See if I don't provoke her jealousy!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)Confusion! a singular part I am playing here! But after all, what is Mabel to me now? (going up, C.)

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (crossing to the Ladies)Foregad! my lady, you wholly absorb our fair stranger.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What, still here, Lord Arthur? I swear I thought I had ordered you from my presence a long hour hence.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: I have been going the whole time.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (coquettishly)What, leave us, my lord, already?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Do you desire my presence, then?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Can you doubt it?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: That's right! Occupy him, sweetheart—that will leave me better opportunities with poor Mr. Frankland. (Lady Glenmorris flinches—but recovers herself) I'll prepare for the Mall. (rings) Mr. Frankland, you are an artist, you shall give me your judgment on my head dress. (low to Glenmorris, who approaches) I permit you to remain by my side.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (low to her)I cannot. If you knew the pangs I endure—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (as before, smiling)Folly! Now, come, if you be very good, I'll find means to dispatch them all.

div.stage: Bramble has led to a seat on the other side Lady Glenmorris, who has crossed, looking back at Glenmorris—Perkup has entered, and arranges the hair of Lady Amaranthe—Bodkin occupies himself with Lady Amaranthe conceitedly— Glenmorris is between the two groups, looking uneasily at his wife.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)I see what it is. She would embarrass me— place me in a false and ridiculous position. Well, since she declares war, so be it. Egad! I'll begin the hostilities myself, by making love to Lady Amaranthe before her face. (goes to her)

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (laughing to Bramble, who has been whispering with her)Oh, no, no—I positively cannot believe a word of what you say.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (to Glenmorris, who looks round uneasily)Why, what ails the man?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Nothing—nothing. But they whisper so strangely yonder.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What matters that to you? Is that your affair?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (coquettishly)Oh, my lord—I conquer hearts! I, a poor country dame, without experience! Oh, lud! what should I do amidst your town toasts—so adroit, that they can be adored by a score of lovers at a time without ever losing one—so clever, that not one of the score perceives he is the dupe of a coquette —so sure of their charms, that they make up their own faces every morning, as they would wind up a clock for the day?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Charming—fascinating!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (to Lady Glenmorris, who is putting on rouge)So, your ladyship wears rouge.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Only a shade.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (to Lady Glenmorris)And think you not, this charm of natural simplicity will turn all heads? I know one already. (aside) I wonder how the widow swallows the pill!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (to Lady Amaranthe)I positively must hire a house close by your own, my dear.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)She is determined to drive me mad.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I mean to live in town for the future—receive a select society of all its brightest gems. Lord Arthur, you must be one of mine.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: With enchantment.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: The distinguished diplomatists of the day shall embellish my drawing-room. (looks to Bodkin)

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (leaving Lady Amaranthe's table, and coming over to Lady Glenmorris)A delirious project, fair lady!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (after receiving Bodkin with a gracious smile— aside) Ah, it works—it works! And it isn't so difficult after all!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)And now, Sir Basil, too! It's growing positively ridiculous!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (to Lady Glenmorris)Yes, yes, you diplomatists have a knowledge, an experience—a—a—je ne sais quoi, which ensures success. (flirts with her.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (getting still more vexed—aloud)Happy the lady who is free to choose her residence; but most have relations—connections, who might object—refuse—prevent—

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (gaily)Oh, 'tis but a husband can do that—and I am free—I am a widow.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: A widow—you, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Yes, sir—a widow. You seem astonished!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: By no means. (aside) It will soon come to much the same thing.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (aside)A widow's always a lure. Oh, she's advancing in her science at full gallop.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: A widow! unfortunate lady!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Perhaps not so much to be pitied after all.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: Ah, I see; your husband was a conceited, selfish, fop. Abominable!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Or a passionate, jealous tyrant. Atrocious!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Why, he had a few good qualities—not many, I own.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: In fact, he was a monster.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: Just like them all.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Well! respect to his memory, gentlemen! The less we speak of him the better.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (low to Glenmorris, who is fidgetting backwards and forwards)What ails you? One would take you for a tower-beast fretting in his cage.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Oh, nothing—nothing. (aside) Impossible to defend myself, or say a word.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Frankland, how like you these pearls?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (looking the other way)Charming—charming!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (to Lady Glenmorris)Happy the man destined to console you!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: There must be some successful conquerer of that heart, you know.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (coquettishly)Oh, I protest nothing—and I promise nothing.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (aside)Egad! she gives me encouragement.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (aside)That glance was for me!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (low to Lady Glenmorris)If I might have the bliss of a few moments conversation with you—alone?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (approaching)Ah—what?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (turning)Hey—did you speak?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (affecting to lower her voice)Who is that young man?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Oh, a Mr. Frankland—an artist.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: A fellow who paints something or other.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Indeed! I don't know the person.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (to Glenmorris, who is walking up and down, enraged)Mr. Frankland—eh! Mr. Frankland! (low to him) If you put on these impatient airs, you had better go at once. (aloud) I am very sorry, but if you have a lesson, I can't detain you.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: We shall be grieved. But pray think of your lesson, Mr. Frankland.

sp.speaker: Bramble., Bodkin.
sp.p: (together)Oh, yes—pray think of your lesson!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (low to Lady Amaranthe—enraged)You drive me out, then?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (low to him)For a few minutes only, foolish creature —till I get rid of the others.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)I am bursting with rage all the same.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you attend my slight repast to-day. Then we have Lady Spangle's masquerade.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: But since you are for the Mall, permit us to swell your escort, as the humblest of your slaves. Mrs. Templemore will there see all the fashion.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (rising)Oh, that will be charming!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (rising—with evident annoyance)Delightful!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (low to Lady Amaranthe)You are going, then?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (low to him)Patience—you shall see. (aloud) Perkup, our mantillas. Exit Perkup.(putting her hand to her head) Ah, ah!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (affecting) A sudden meagrim—the vapours of this morning. (falls into her chair)

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside)Ah, she wants to remain alone—for him! (putting her hand to her heart) Ah, ah!

sp.speaker: The Three Men.
sp.p: (turning towards her)What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Oh, a dreadful palpitation—the fatigues of my journey—oh! (falls into her chair)

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)Both at once! The devil!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (aside)She too! She doesn't comprehend me.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (low and quick to Bramble)You had better not go.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: I understand. Ravishing creature!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (busied about Lady Glenmorris)Poor little darling! I am so moved by sympathy, I think I shall have an attack too.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Impossible to leave you thus. (sits, L.)

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (low to him)That's right.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (low to Lady Amaranthe)Lord Arthur remains, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (low to him)Now fly in a passion again, monster. You don't deserve that I should say—come back.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (low to Lady Glenmorris)It were wiser to go, and return immediately. (rises—aloud) There—all goes better now. Come, Sir Basil, we will leave the ladies.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: I am sure I could have done them good. I always do!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (low to Glenmorris) I have succeeded—she gives me a rendezvous.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)Ha! and no means of cramming the words down his cursed throat—not that I care for the base woman! But she has borne my name.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (low to Glenmorris)Get rid of your friend.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (low to Lady Amaranthe)You had better keep that Mrs. What's-her-name locked up out of the way. (aside) At all events, I will prevent their rendezvous. Exit, hurriedly, C. D.

p.stage: Adieu, mes toutes belles! Come, Sir Basil!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: I am sure I could have done them a world of good. Exit, with Bramble, C. D. (Lady Amaranthe and Lady Glenmorris both burst out laughing)

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (with affected simplicity)I hope I have shown myself an apt scholar, love.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (still laughing)If you mean in the art of upsetting all my schemes—assuredly.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (as before—rising)I followed your example.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: The very last thing you should have done. By detaining Lord Arthur, and remaining yourself, you prevented my being alone with that poor Mr. Frankland.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (as before)Oh, did I? I'm sure I am very sorry. I'll leave you, then, at once.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: When it is too late. (rises)

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: You should have made me a sign. You know I am a poor, inexperienced, ignorant creature.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Well, no matter now, sweetheart—the harm is small.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: You will contrive to see him again, then—alone?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes, and perhaps the crisis of my fate is nigh.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (seeking to know)Ah, indeed!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Alas! there must be a conclusion to every drama, even that of a professed coquette—surrender and marriage. Leonard loves me; and if, after one last explanation, I declare myself—Yes, to-night, at Lady Spangle's masquerade—he is invited.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (as before)Well!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You shall know all hereafter.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (disappointed)Ah!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Continue to occupy Lord Arthur Bramble.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: There's no difficulty in that—he's coming back.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: For you?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: For me.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (somewhat piqued)The monster! Well, no matter, I thought I had some regard for the wretch once—and had not another come in the way—who knows? But that's all over now. So keep him, sweetheart—I resign him without a pang— the false traitor! the—the—only promise me to break his heart for him—and then I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: But tell me first—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Not now. (goes to R. D., and returns) Mind, you must break Lord Arthur's heart—make him suffer, love—suffer, d'ye hear? the weak, wavering fellow! (aside, going) A woman may love one man, but she never can bear to see another desert her colours—it's always an abomination. Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: What can she mean to do? I am lost in a chaos of doubt. But the spirit of vengeance is aroused in me, and I'll fight to the last, for the good of humanity—in the cause of neglected wives. I'll coquette with the whole male race—It's so amusing to see them dying before one! But, no, no! let me learn the strategy of the coquette in self-defence—not as a means of heartless attack. Ah, Lord Arthur!Enter Lord Arthur Bramble, C. D.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Alone, fairest! Exquisite opportunity!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I expected you, my lord. I have not the art of your town coquettes—I am frank and straitforward; and I will avow to you a truth, which, doubtless, you are unaccustomed to learn.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: No, no—I am tolerably accustomed to such things. You would avow to me that—

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: That I can never love you.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (disappointed)Ah! (aside) I must say, I did not expect that.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I admit your powers of pleasing—but a previous affection—deep as it is unhappy—absorbs my every feeling.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Enough—enough, madam. Certainly, I had fancied that—in fact—but I have the honour of wishing you a very good day. (going)

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Do not leave me thus. Affection for another excludes neither friendship or interest. I will be frank again— you love Lady Amaranthe.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: I own it. My heart—my true, real, genuine heart is hers. But she does not love me.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: She loves you alone. But alarmed by your jealous temper—

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: My jealous temper! What a calumny! Did I know my rival, I'd slit the rascal's ears for him.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (laughing)Ha, ha, ha! right or wrong, she fears to confide to you her future welfare; and, although she loves you, might listen to the proposals of another, who designs, it seems, to profit by this masquerade to lure her into his clutches.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: But what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Watch her movements at this masquerade—follow her—thwart this fellow's designs—show her your claims to gratitude; and then, abjuring that impatient temper—

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Temper again! Temper! when I am the most reasonable and composed of men.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Well, no—you are right. I will moderate my temper—and marriage is a wonderful sedative. You shall see how I shall calm down when she is mine. Oh, you are an angel. (seizes her hand and kisses it.)Enter Perkup, C. D., with a letter.

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: Hum! (Lady Glenmorris and Bramble go asunder—aside) So, madam makes the best use of her time.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Well, girl, what do you want?

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: A letter for your lor'ship, left by a street porter, who said 'twas in urgent haste. (Bramble snatches the letter— aside) Not that I think his lor'ship was in any hurry for it. Oh, these fine ladies! how they do lead those men by the nose —I mean by the lips. Exit, C. D.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Permit me!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside—after looking over his shoulder)My husband's handwriting!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (to himself)Strange missive! but it is to my address. Egad! I'll give a lesson to this insolent scribe!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: A little matter of business calls me away.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I see what it is—some rendezvous. Poor Aramanthe!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: I assure you no!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: But I am convinced it is.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (giving her the letter)Judge for yourself, and understand the mystery if you can—for I cannot.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (reading)“A gentleman whom you have mortally offended” (aside) Heavens! (reading) “demands instant satisfaction of you, and awaits you alone by Rosamond's pond.”

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: And no signature!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside)Ah, this is terrible! could I have known—

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: You tremble for me! how kind! but fear nothing—I am sure of my lunge.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I can never suffer you to expose yourself thus to danger.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: You are charming. But in such an affair, all the world will tell you I must listen only to honour's dictates.Enter Sir Aubrey Glenmorris, C. D.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)He does not come; and my uncontrolable impatience—Ah! still together.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (C.)Ask Mr. Frankland here!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (R., aside)Good heavens! (up stage)

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Now, my good fellow, read that, (gives letter to Sir Aubrey) and say how a man should act in such a case.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Can Lord Arthur Bramble ask the question?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: There—what did I say? I fly!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: And I will follow you. (going)

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (flinging herself between them—hastily to Bramble)You shall not go!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside)Heaven inspire me! (aloud) Women understand not all the niceties of what men call honour; but sense alone suggests that honour cannot demand the acceptance of a challenge, without name avowed—without motives indicated.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: They can easily be learned. (pointedly) The challenger awaits Lord Arthur.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: He does not. (pointedly) I am sure he is not at the place of meeting.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: But he will be there.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Then he will be there alone, for (turning to Lord Arthur) you shall not stir from hence. I command you— stay!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)She commands, now! she must be possessed.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: In the name of one so dear to you—who loves you so tenderly, you know—one who would not survive your loss.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)She avows her passion under my very nose.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: But my dear lady—

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (low to Bramble)But suppose it should be a trick of this unknown rival to get you out of the way—take advantage of your absence.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (low)What a ray of light! yes, yes, an anonymous challenge! I should be left to cool my heels by Rosamond's pond, while he—'tis evident—in fact, a very clumsy trick. (aloud) I shall not go.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (with joy)Ah!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: My lord!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: No, no, I shall not go. I'm not to be caught like a gudgeon, gadslife! (low to Lady Glenmorris) I'll not quit my widow for a moment.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (low to Bramble)'Tis the wisest resolution.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)Whispering again! confusion!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: So! I have your promise to accept no provocation without my permission. (he hesitates) I insist upon it—do you hear? (smiling) I insist upon it.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)Now she insists. She is possessed, 'tis clear!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (kissing the hand of Lady G.)I yield—you are an angel.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)And no means of vengeance! oh, my rage! (advancing.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (hastily placing herself between them)Sir!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (low to her, with rage)So! you tremble for him, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (low)And were it not for him?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (checking himself—with joy)What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (coming down again to Lady G.)You are my guardian angel. (to Sir Aubrey) That's a charming woman, my dear sir—an adorable woman. Exit, C. D.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside)I must not forget my lesson.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Did I hear aright? is it possible? (Lady Glenmorris goes C. D.) You leave me without a word?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (coldly)I am not aware that we have further business to discuss.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: But surely that expression of interest in my fate—

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: What! did I say anything? I swear I never meant it. You have often reproached me with talking like a silly child; so, pray pay no heed to any folly I may utter.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (disappointed)Indeed! I was deceived, then. Permit me, at least, the privilege to speak.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Provided you be quick.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (with constraint)Madam, although the ties which existed between us will be shortly severed, some interest may survive—on my part; and I cannot see you falling down a precipice—plunged into the whirlpool of a society—

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (interrupting)Which you have made your own. Can I take a better model for my future conduct than a woman whom you so much admire? Surely you cannot blame the lightness of a coquette, who is happy only in the number of her admirers and her dupes. You follow in her train—you swell her ranks—you applaud—approve—can you condemn me?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (curtseying)Your pardon, sir, I am in haste— arrangements to make for the masquerade—an engagement to settle with Lord Arthur Bramble. (going)

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (stopping her)I understand your impatience, madam, but I cannot forget that I have been—that I am your husband. Spite of all, memory will retrace those days gone by—

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (laughing with affectation)Oh, dear—oh dear! there's nothing on earth so easy as to forget—I find it so.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (piqued)Indeed! what, have you no souvenir of a love once tender and sincere?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (restraining her natural impulse)Heaven help the man! there's nothing so tiresome and silly as a heart that really loves. I must have wearied you to extinction. I gave my whole heart and soul to you. Ha, ha, ha! It must have been ruefully fatiguing.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: And are you, then, so wholly changed?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (with coquetry)Well, perhaps, not quite.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (eagerly)Ah! then you—

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (checking herself)Oh, don't be uneasy. The change will speedily be complete.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Mabel, were it true—Enter Sir Basil Bodkin, C. D.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: Lovely Mrs. Templemore, I was seeking you everywhere.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)The foul fiend seize the fool.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: All the world is in the gallery. The new cotillon must be practised for the masquerade. The fiddlers are there, but the string to all hearts fails. (aside) That was pretty.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (low to Lady G.)Mabel I must speak to you—I entreat you, hear me.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside)Only too willingly, did I yet think myself secure. (aloud, paying no heed to Glenmorris) Sir Basil, I attend you—Mr. Frankland, sorry to quit you; but dances and dresses are important affairs of state for women. Au revoir.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: I shall see you, then, again, madam?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (coquettishly)Who knows? Well, perhaps. Sir Basil, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (aside, as he gives her his hand)She adores me! My diplomatic tact is sure of success with them all. Exit with Lady Glenmorris, C. D.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p:
That last look gave me hope. Hope! what do I mean by hope? Zounds! I no longer know what I hope—
what I desire—even what I feel. What madness possesses a man to pursue these brilliant meteors of fashion, that flicker thus, false lights, before our eyes—now luring one—now fascinating another—and to disdain the true star of love—a pure confiding heart, that shines steadily to one's own, and mirror's there its sole affection. Fools are we all! Ah, were there still time to arrest Mabel—It is my duty! (going hastily, C. D.)

div.stage: Enter Lady Amaranthe, R. D.—she wears a domino, and holds her mask in her hand.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (R., aside)He is there—I thought so. (aloud— calling) Mr. Frankland!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)Lady Amaranthe! at this moment!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I guessed you would await me here, you naughty, confident man!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (embarrassed)Certainly! My only thought was for you. (aside) What is Mabel doing now?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I pretended the necessity of a change in the trimming of my domino to leave my guests—for I knew your impatience.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Certainly. (aside) She will be listening to the flatteries of those cursed fools!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I would have come sooner, but Lord Arthur Bramble persecuted me with fresh protestations.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (with hope)Then he no longer courts that Mrs. Templemore.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (shrugging her shoulders)Oh! the monster was only deceiving me; for I caught them exchanging signs of intelligence.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: So are those traitors—men—ever affecting most tenderness when they most design to break their chains. They are now practising the new dance together.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)She is dancing—dancing with him, while I— I—am dancing, too, but on hot irons.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (aside)I could have torn the traitor's eyes out. But what matter? My heart is not his—I feel it is wholly another's now. (aloud to Sir Aubrey, who is going up C. D.) Mr. Frankland, we have to speak together seriously. I feel, in according this interview, which you have so earnestly desired, a strange oppression—

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (eagerly)A return of the vapours! Nothing like gaiety to dissipate them. Suppose I lead you back to the company in the gallery.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
What! when the whole day you have sought
to be alone with me in vain. Such abnegation I did not expect. Come sit down, there—by my side.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside)I cannot stand this!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (seated)You have much to tell me.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (holding the chair without sitting)I?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes—for before further explanations, you must dissipate the mystery that surrounds you, for mystery there is.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (not attending to her)Certainly! (goes up)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: So you avow it! Ah! you have been wrong to deceive me with insincerity. Come, confess all—I listen.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (aside at C. D., looking out)Yes! there she is! What's that? A note put into her hand! She approaches the window to read it! Oh, confusion! that is too much! Exit hastily, C. D.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: So, shame ties your tongue. Must I encourage you? Speak, then, and I, in turn, will tell you of the plans that I have formed. (looking round) Gone? when I expected a fervid declaration—What does this mean? I'm thunderstruck! Enter Sir Basil Bodkin, C. D. Sir Basil! Well, in the general desertion, I am sure of the constancy of my lay figure. (aloud to Bodkin, who is hunting about) What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: Ah, fair lady—I did not see you.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: I was seeking for a fan—Mrs. Templemore's fan.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mabel again!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: She is suffocating with heat, poor dear little woman. She has been dancing with an incomparable grace. Ye gods, how she did dance! I don't see her fan. (going)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (L., with impatience)Sir Basil!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (R)I never saw any sylph so airy. She inspired me so, that I could have tripped myself like another sylph. Foregad! I could—It was all I could do to keep myself from —(beginning to dance) I can't find her fan. (going)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Did I not bid you stay, Sir Basil? But this is unbearable! She has turned every head then?

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: Braybabble is dumb with admiration. Lord Faddle lisps more pathetically than ever. Fripperycourt has laid his scented gloves at her feet; and Captain Simper has positively found his tongue to express his devotion. It's a general conflagration! Where the deuce is this fan?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (stamping with her foot)Stay, I tell you! And even you, it seems, have been scorched by the flame, Sir Basil?

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: What, you saw me—at her feet?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: At her feet!—he too!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (aside)Eh, eh! a slip of the tongue—from a diplomatist too—incredible! But it's the first time.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You—you too! (aside) My very lay figure—my butt—my man of straw seduced!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: I don't know how it was. My habit of constant success—I could not help it. But my heart is yours.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (walking about in a fever of impatience—aside)So, it seems I have taught a lesson for personal application—given arms to be directed against myself—raised a spirit that turns to rend me. An old friend, too! fool and dupe that I am!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (following her—aside)She seems irate! (aloud) But my heart is only yours, you know.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (as before)But should Leonard also fall into her nets—I cannot bear the thought. My project must be hastened at all ventures. I can best escape from observation during the confusion of the masquerade. Mabel, dressed in the domino similar to this, shall remain at the ball, and unwittingly serve my plan. A secret marriage shall make me his for ever. By degrees, the world may know the proud woman's weakness.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (as before—aside)She is uncommon difficult to mollify. (aloud) But my heart is only yours, and yours alone.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What did you say?

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (aside)She wants me to repeat the fond words. (aloud) But my heart—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I have no time to speak of trifles now.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: Trifles! my heart a trifle!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Hear me, Sir Basil—(aside) He may be of service. But what excuse can I invent?

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: I am waiting to hear. (aside) Will she confess her love at last?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (with a sudden thought)Ah, Sir Basil, I am weary of this life. I quit London for the country—this very night.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: Alone?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: No, no—a true friend shall accompany me as—as—

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: Your husband. (aside) I knew she would come to me!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Let a hackney carriage await me at the corner of Lady Spangle's Street—I would escape all observation—leave the world to learn my departure only by my absence. At this masked ball keep near me, at a little distance, without speaking —you will recognise this domino. (aside) Mabel will have the other—he will follow her.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: Good—good! (aside) I carry off the prize—I was sure of it.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Await my signal to depart.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (aside)She's mine.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (aside)He'll wait all night. (aloud) Now go—see that the carriage is ready.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: Oh, if the gratitude of a grateful and gratified heart—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Not another word—begone!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: I go. (aside, going) I am born for success! Exit, C. D.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes, yes—this very night the humble Leonard Frankland shall have my hand. No indecision more—I will be strong—or weak—which shall I call it? I scarce know myself! Enter Lady Glenmorris, C. D. Mabel! the horrid little flirt! I have no patience with her!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (L.)I am delighted to find you, sweetheart!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (R.—with ill repressed spite)Come, let me felicitate you, love.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I have done my best—I thought you would be pleased with me.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (as before)I am enchanted. For a first lesson you have profitted marvellously, I must admit. One would have thought you had been a professor yourself all your life.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: You flatter me.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Oh, no.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: You say that so singularly. Are you vexed that I should be courted by all the men?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: On the contrary—even though they be all my own adorers.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (smiling)You told me, you know, that I must learn to embrace my dearest friend, and yet carry off her lovers.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (aside)Is this simplicity or artifice? (aloud) Your domino is in your room, sweetheart. Keep closely masked at Lady Spangle's. Prudence dictates this course—and should you miss me, return here.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Nothing. (sits)

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (aside)I tremble.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You will be ready? (sits, turning her back, sulkily.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p:
I will. (aside, going) She has some design. Ought I not to reveal all? And yet—not to be sure of Aubrey. No, pardon me, Amaranthe, if still a short time longer I keep my secret. Ah, 'tis he!
(she hastily enters the room, L., and looks out occasionally during the following scene)

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (at the door, holding a bouquet in his hand)Perfidious woman! she disarms my anger by a look of tenderness—gives me her flowers to hold as a gage of kindly feeling, and then disappears at the same time as Lord Arthur. (throws down the bouquet)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (R.—turning at this last movement)Leonard! (rises) Ah, you are come! If you knew all my doubts and fears!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (L.)Yours!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes—hear me. We may be interrupted every moment—tell me, do you love me still?

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (confused)Love you! yes—I—(aside) At least I hate Mabel now.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Well, then—(with effort) Mr. Frankland—Leonard —you have supplicated at my feet, often and ardently—I may have received the attentions of others—of one other for whom I thought once to have a lurking preference—but the coquette is gone! you have triumphed over all—my hand is yours.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (in confusion)Your hand!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes. I would not that the world should know this at once. Here I am observed. At Lady Spangle's masquerade I have arranged all, that we may depart together—a secret marriage shall unite us—and then—But you are pale, confused.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (embarassed)With delight! (aside) What shall I say and do?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Then at last I make one being happy.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (as before)Yes, very happy.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (aside) And if I can wring one pang from Lord Arthur's heart, I am revenged on him.

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: Oh, lud, your la'ship, the gentlemen will fall a fighting next among themselves, if your la'ship is not soon ready to start for the masquerade. And all for Madame Templemore!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Indeed! Await me here, Mr. Frankland. Come, Perkup. (aside) 'Tis done! the die is cast! Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: (going)If I don't set Taggs and the others fighting about me, too, I'm no woman. 'Tis such fun! Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p:
Into what a labyrinth of error has my folly plunged me. Lady Amaranthe accepts me—and Mabel, shameful woman! when all my love revived—no, I will tear her utterly
from my heart. (snatches up the bouquet) Would I could crush my affection as I now crush these flowers. What's this, in the midst of the flowers? a billet doux! from my rival— that accursed Lord Arthur Bramble. (flinging down the flowers, and opening the note) Yes, it is from him! (reading with agitation) “Most generous of women—your advice shall be followed. I have arranged all, so as to protect her I love from a rival, and make her mine.” Her he loves! torture! “May the same happiness be yours—and that unhappy love, you say, is the only thought of your existence, be rewarded by the repentance of the false one.” What does this mean? It is not he then? But who—Ah, can it be possible? Can Mabel love me still? Lady Glenmorris has entered—she goes up a little and drops down, R. C.—she is dressed in a similar domino to Lady Amaranthe, and is masked. Oh, I must see her—speak with her. (turns) Heavens! Lady Amaranthe!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (advancing—changing her voice)Are you ready? Come.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (in the greatest agitation)No, never—it cannot be! Hear me—hear the confession of a wretched criminal. (Lady Glenmorris totters) Ha, she grows faint! (leads her to a chair) Pity me—pardon me if you can—I have deceived you, and another, whose pure affection I disdained, has resumed her empire over my heart—I love her alone—and if she restores me not her lost affection, I feel that life will be worthless.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (weeping)Oh!

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: You weep?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Yes, but it is with joy. (takes off her mask)

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Mabel!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (C.)Oh, recall not the words that you have uttered (Glenmorris kneels at her feet)—those words that have restored me to bliss unutterable. Aubrey! I have never ceased to love you—my coquetry was affected—my coldness was the bitterest constraint. The only prize I sought was your affection.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: (L., rising)Is this a dream—or do I now awake? Oh, Mabel, how expiate my injustice, my cruelty to thee!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (rising, with fervour)By accepting my love, and my oblivion of all. (she flings herself into his arms)

div.stage: Enter Bramble, C. D., down R.—Lady Glenmorris hastily resumes her mask.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: What do I see? Lady Amaranthe in his arms! Treachery! there, then, is my rival! The painter, whom I never once suspected! But he shall give me satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Satisfaction you shall have, my lord.

div.stage: Enter Lady Amaranthe, hastily, R., followed by Peukup.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What words of anger are these?

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (with the utmost surprise)Lady Amaranthe! are there two, then? (Lady Glenmorris takes off her mask) Mrs. Templemore!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (aside)What do I see? Oh, my prophetic fears!

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: What does all this signify? I am lost in a maze!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: A word from me will explain all. I have sought and found a truant husband.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Her husband! Oh, Mabel, Mabel!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: (crossing)Amaranthe! (the following between the Women low)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You have deceived me basely.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Pardon me—had I revealed all at once, he had not been reclaimed. He had fled me in confusion, and—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And I was your victim. Know you into what a gulf of perdition you had nigh plunged me?

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: I know that I would make you happy by urging you to accept the hand of an honest man, who really loves you. (points to Bramble.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: But I really don't understand.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: You will understand, I hope, when I tell you that Lady Amaranthe accepts your homage and your hand.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: (aside)Well, I believe the creature is sincere— and—who knows? past delusive errors will fly before the sober realities of matrimony. (aloud) Lord Arthur. (holds out her hand.

sp.speaker: Bramble.
sp.p: (going to her) My adored Amaranthe!

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: Let oblivion and forgiveness be our motto. I leave London with my husband—when we return may the past be pardoned and forgotten. (Lady Amaranthe bows coldly)Enter Bodkin, C. D.

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (coming down to Lady Amaranthe, and whispering)The coach is ready at the street corner. To-night will make me a happy man. (aside) I was sure of success.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You must be mad, Sir Basil! Have you taken a masquerade mystification for a reality? Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p: (aside)Eh! you don't mean to say—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I mean to say that I have accepted Lord Arthur, and have taken Sir Aubrey and Lady Glenmorris as witnesses of my contract. (turns to Bramble)

sp.speaker: Bodkin.
sp.p:
Lord Arthur accepted! Sir Aubrey—Lady Glen— my head spins round! Beaten! impossible! I was so sure of
my habitual success. What's come to the sex? Ha, that damsel winks at me—my merit is appreciated still!

sp.speaker: Perkup.
sp.p: (aside)The man is positively ogling me. Now they are all pairing like the beasts in Noah's ark—I might have a chance with him.

sp.speaker: Lady G.
sp.p: From henceforth, Aubrey, I renounce my coquetry of a day. I have gained all the honours I sought in passing my examination in “The School for Coquettes.”

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And yet, 'tis not you have received the lesson.
sp.l: From childhood's simpleness to latest age,
If all will read aright life's meaning page,
They still may learn good lessons to the last,
By studying the moral of the past—
And happy those, who are not chid as “fool,”
But gain applause by what they do at “school.”

div.p: * If considered advisable, the piece may be played in Two Acts, by the following slight alteration at page 17. After the words: “I deserved better at her hands!”

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: No matter! I am free now! My widow's there! so now to swear and sigh that I'm her slave—to prove my liberty! Exit, C. D.

div.stage: SCENE—(Same) Enter Sir Aubrey Glenmorris, C. D.

sp.speaker: Glen.
sp.p: Not a word can I have with her amidst the crowd! Ah! here she comes—but not alone!
